text.p: France welcomed Wednesday's historic deal between NATO and Russia aimed at creating a new peaceful relationship, and said that Paris and Bonn deserved some of the credit.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt reaffirmed French willingness to host a ceremony in Paris on May 27 to sign an accord that would sweep aside Moscow's concerns over the expansion of the Western defence alliance.

The text of the deal was agreed in Moscow by Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov and NATO Secretary General Javier Solana after months of tough talks. The text has to be approved by NATO governments and Russian President Boris Yeltsin.

"If there was confirmation, this would be an historic event because it would be an essential element in a new definition of the European security architecture, giving Russia its full place," Rummelhardt told a routine briefing.
"It has been made possible thanks to the joint action of all, notably of France and Germany," he said. "France, which was at the origin of these ideas, is particularly pleased."
Solana and Primakov said Wednesday's agreement opened the way for Moscow and the Western alliance to sign the security deal on May 27 in the French capital.
